title: Excepting Administrative Law Judges From the Competitive Service

enrichment.summary: This executive order changes how administrative law judges (ALJs) are hired by removing them from the traditional competitive hiring process and placing their appointments into an excepted service category. This allows agencies more flexibility to select ALJs based on qualities like judgment and legal ability, aiming to improve the quality and constitutional soundness of these important judicial appointments.
potential_concerns: Excluding administrative law judges (ALJs) from competitive service hiring may reduce transparency and increase the risk of politicized or biased appointments within federal agencies, potentially impacting the impartiality expected of ALJs and trust in agency adjudications.

Greater agency discretion in hiring ALJs could lead to inconsistent qualification standards across agencies, potentially disadvantaging qualified candidates and undermining merit-based hiring principles for federal employees.

The removal of competitive examination and rating procedures might inadvertently diminish opportunities for veterans to obtain ALJ positions, despite the order's reference to veteran preference 'as far as administratively feasible,' posing equity concerns for this population.

The shift to excepted service status for ALJs may result in legal challenges or confusion concerning the status and protections of ALJs currently in competitive service, impacting their job security and employment conditions.
